> Can you try enabling debug logging for org.apache.pulsar.broker.service.persistent.MessageDeduplication? 

The broker outputed a lot of logs as follow:
```
08:33:16.719 [bookkeeper-ml-workers-OrderedExecutor-3-0] DEBUG o.a.p.b.s.p.MessageDeduplication     - [persistent://XXXXX/global/deduplication/p-topic2-partition-3] Taking snapshot of sequence ids map

```

`brokerDeduplicationEntriesInterval` is 1 on this broker. This may be affecting.
However,  this issue occurs even if `brokerDeduplicationEntriesInterval` is default value(1000).

@aahmed-se  That's a different issue

>  what is the before and after size?

we're cutting in half the size of pulsar distribution (which is ~286MB).

The problem with using the tgz is that we have 2 operations: 
```
ADD ${PULSAR_TARBALL} /	
RUN mv /apache-pulsar-* /pulsar
```

The `mv` operation is creating a new additional layer with a copy of the directory.

BTW, integration tests are failing because the maven resource plugin is messing up with the execution bit while copying the scripts.

I think I need to recollect dedup code little bit but from where exactly `initialize()` method is being called.? I think cursor is being set-inactive as soon as it's [recovered](https://github.com/apache/pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-broker/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/broker/service/persistent/MessageDeduplication.java#L241). I don't see any code-path that actually calls `initialize()` method?
did you get change to run broker with this change? just want to make sure that we won't have any runtime exception here..

Currently it's only set inactive on 
https://github.com/apache/pulsar/blob/8b2929b3e5403fb44653976dc74be287666f7b96/pulsar-broker/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/broker/service/persistent/MessageDeduplication.java#L239-L242 which is called the first time the dedup is enabled (or if there is any discrepancy enabled/disabled) but it's not being set on the cursor when the topic (and the dedup) cursor is being recovered.

The integration tests job is using the docker images, which are built from the distribution tgz. Any jar missing at runtime will show up there. 
(it does actually appear there some issue with the functions runtime deps on https://builds.apache.org/job/pulsar_precommit_integrationtests/6594/ )

This issue is led by a mistake in pulsar-client-cpp/BatchAcknowledgementTracker.cc.
This is fixed in master https://github.com/apache/pulsar/pull/3618

Hi @sijie I am slightly confused on how to create this REST endpoint. A non-partitioned topic is created in ```internalCreateSubscription```, but functions as a temporary topic from which a subscription could be created. So if we created a non-partitioned PersistentTopic outside of this method, what would we do with it?

My reasoning here is that a non-partitioned topic is only created if the user had not bothered to create a partitioned topic. From the way the code is organized, it appears that a non-partitioned topic is constructed only when a ```Z-Node``` for that topic does not exist (kind of implying that the user does not create a non-partitioned topic, only pulsar internals does).

In our previous discussion on the issue, I remember that ```createPartitionedTopic``` needed to be improved. I noticed that there is a precondition which prevents the number of partitions from being created to be less than two. So my understanding here is that we should remove this condition (i.e. allow the creation of a topic with no partitions) ? How this method is to be improved in admittedly difficult for me to see.

We should do the improvements you suggested in any case, though I'm not 100 convinced the builder stuff is necessary.

> A non-partitioned topic is created in `internalCreateSubscription`, but functions as a temporary topic from which a subscription could be created. So if we created a non-partitioned PersistentTopic outside of this method, what would we do with it?

Currently the default behavior is a non-partitioned topic automatically created when a consumer subscribe or a publisher publishes a message. With you previous change, we disable this auto-creation. so the endpoint is the only way to create the non-partitioned topic. If a topic is created by the rest endpoint, when consumer/publisher connect, they will be realizing that the topic has been created. they will continue consuming or publishing messages.

> I remember that `createPartitionedTopic` needed to be improved. I noticed that there is a precondition which prevents the number of partitions from being created to be less than two. So my understanding here is that we should remove this condition (i.e. allow the creation of a topic with no partitions) ?

I think that should be a different pull request and a separated discussion. Changing the behavior of creating partitioned topic (e.g. allow creating a partitioned topic with only 1 partition) should be discussed at dev@ mailing list. It should be done via a PIP, since it is a user facing behavior change though.

closed the request based on last comment. since Pulsar Processors for Apache NiFi

@sijie On a related note, I heard back from the NiFi team that they are no longer accepting new processor contributions including the Pulsar processors I submitted. 

"Might be a good idea to release this as your own bundle. We're starting to hit a point where the PMC and committers are struggling to keep up in terms of expertise with the diversity of thing being offered for official inclusion. I recall this being something that your company wants to push to support its own offerings, so I think it might make sense to have Streamlio put it up on their github repo and we can help advertise it to the NiFi community.

(Also, FYI, Apache Infra is starting to balk at giving us more storage space on mirrors because our tarball is I think now over 1.6GB)"

So maybe we will need to a way to package and release that code from the Pulsar repository
I would suggest you double checking the runtime-all jar to make sure shading are done correctly. otherwise functions will be broken when running in process mode.

run java8 tests

> * seeking by earliest / latest can just seek on all partitions. 

Agree. It doesn't make sense not to support earliest/latest... 

> 2\. seeking by messageId is also doable. because messageId provides partition id.

If the seek operation only affects the cursor in one partition, it might become confusing to a user, since it's a different behavior from the above. 

In general, I'm not a big fan of seek by message id on the consumer interface, since the purpose of `Consumer` should be that the reading position is "managed" by the system. If an application wants to position to a particular message id, it's more of manual handling and maybe `Reader` is a better option there.

> * python state 

That one is there ;)
